text: What is the company culture like at the new place? A challenge is always great but you need to be surrounded by the right folk if you want to blossom. I've worked in various startups, and what works for me and what works for you aren't necessarily the same, but if you can have a "culture fit" call with potential future colleagues, I'd recommend it. Because in the end, the product is important, but the people much more.

elements.text: What is the company culture like at the new place? A challenge is always great but you need to be surrounded by the right folk if you want to blossom. Because in the end, the product is important, but the people much more.

text:
I'm personally very motivated by product and I tend to be attracted to visionary products that are disrupting existing processes or systems, but they don't always have full product-market fit yet when I first join ... and that can absolutely be chaotic. Messaging pivots, last minute product releases, chasing shiny objects, feast or famine revenue attainment, rapid hiring and layoffs, etc. Be prepared for a bit of a rollercoaster going in at that stage. Some people love it, others don't and it's an incredible source of stress.

For a "cutting edge data" product, I recommend digging in to the source of the data - first party, third party, biggest risks to disruption, etc - as well as how real the product is compared to the vision the leadership paints. The product roadmap is an important input for content strategy, so knowing where the product is today and where it's going can have a huge impact on your work. If they don't have a product marketing function yet, you may also be asked to produce some of that content.

elements.text:

text: Hi there would love some career path advice. I recently transitioned from full-time freelance copywriter to full-time lead content writer. As a full-time employee I'm really missing the autonomy and flexibility of self-employment. However, I also love having a say in the content strategy, learning deeply about the product through being an internal team member, and editing the work of freelancers. I find myself in this weird in-between stage  where simply going back to freelance writing wouldnt be enough but I also don't know the next step in my "content lead" career. Are there consulting / contractor roles for content leads? Has anyone been through a similar transition or caught between full-time employment and freelancing?

elements.text: Hi there would love some career path advice. I recently transitioned from full-time freelance copywriter to full-time lead content writer. As a full-time employee I'm really missing the autonomy and flexibility of self-employment. However, I also love having a say in the content strategy, learning deeply about the product through being an internal team member, and editing the work of freelancers. I find myself in this weird in-between stage  where simply going back to freelance writing wouldnt be enough but I also don't know the next step in my "content lead" career. Are there consulting / contractor roles for content leads? Has anyone been through a similar transition or caught between full-time employment and freelancing?

text: Yeah there are a bunch of women doing this. Kaleigh Moore, Jessica Malnik. They often sell a content strategy and then ongoing content production.

elements.text: Yeah there are a bunch of women doing this. Kaleigh Moore, Jessica Malnik. They often sell a content strategy and then ongoing content production.

text: Echoing the comment above a bit, I definitely think there is an opportunity to define some "productized services" in strategic areas like positioning, content strategy, etc. that complement your copywriting work. Like you, I also missed going in-depth on a specific product set when I moved to freelance. One thing that helped with this is really niching down. Instead of working with any B2B tech vendor as I did early on, I now only work with cybersecurity startups. It's still not quite the same as working for one company, but it allows me to get more into the details on the market and companies I work with. Also, the fact that I have very focused domain expertise differentiates me and makes it more likely that clients will seek my opinion versus viewing me as someone to go execute their ideas. Picking a segment of the B2B market that you really like and/or have experience with might allow you to do the same.

text:
I write for two tech companies (usually about AI and various coding languages). I knew NOTHING about either of these before writing for the clients.

I learn a lot on the fly, started studying on my own free time to be more prepared the next time around, I usually try to watch a few videos on the topic I am researching for them, and I get really nerdy about keywords for Tech through several different keyword tools.

I hope that helps some! Others above have better advice than I do, though, I think!

I hope that helps some! Others above have better advice than I do, though, I think!

text:
Great question! A few thoughts:

• If you're in a content role, it's much more motivating when your product/customers are interesting. So it definitely plays a big role for me. But what's interesting will be different for everyone :slightly_smiling_face: 
• On that note, the type of product it is and what the sales cycle looks like will hugely affect what type of content you're making. I was previously at an enterprise-esque company and I ended up having to focus primarily on sales enablement content (case studies, slide decks), whereas my interest at the time was more top/middle funnel SEO.
• It sounds like you're in a "marketing to marketers" role right now. It's fun to get outside of that box eventually to learn how to do customer research, learn how to make content when you're not a subject matter expert, etc.

elements.text: If you're in a content role, it's much more motivating when your product/customers are interesting. So it definitely plays a big role for me. But what's interesting will be different for everyone

On that note, the type of product it is and what the sales cycle looks like will hugely affect what type of content you're making. I was previously at an enterprise-esque company and I ended up having to focus primarily on sales enablement content (case studies, slide decks), whereas my interest at the time was more top/middle funnel SEO.

It sounds like you're in a "marketing to marketers" role right now. It's fun to get outside of that box eventually to learn how to do customer research, learn how to make content when you're not a subject matter expert, etc.

text: I work with some clients as essentially a production content writer, and with others as more of a content strategy consultant supplemented with some content production. The latter definitely provides some of that in-depth involvement and ownership over strategy, and I know plenty of consultants who handle freelance writers as well on behalf of their clients. I find the mix of both kinds of work keeps me engaged (I was an in-house content lead for about a decade before going freelance) while still providing the flexibility and autonomy that I don’t think I could ever give up :wink:
